p: CHIKV is an Alphavirus from the Togaviridae family that is transmitted via the bite of infected Aaedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes [ 5, 6]. CHIKV infection results in a dengue-like febrile disease, whose acute phase is characterized by high fever, macular or maculopapular rash, backache, headache, fatigue, myalgia, and polyarthralgia [ 7]. Patients may also develop a later chronic condition, with persistent or relapse symptoms of arthropathy [ 7]. As the majority of CHIKV infected patients are symptomatic with varying degrees of joint or musculoskeletal pains and require long-term treatment, CHIKV represents a serious burden inflected on both public health and economic sector [ 7â€“ 9].
